author: Gregory Karp
title: Baggage re-claim: United turns old banners into bags
text:
United Airlines thinks you can make it a banner day in the Friendly Skies when you find room in the overhead for reincarnated luggage.
The airline teamed up with fashion studies students at Columbia College Chicago and the Re:new Project to make travel bags out of more than 20 old "Fly the Friendly Skies" fabric banners that used to hang in O'Hare International Airport.
The banners became about 100 carry-on backpacks and duffels that were hand-sewn and feature skyline images from the airline's hub cities, United said.
Bags are available Friday at unitedshop.com . The backpacks will sell for $135 and the duffels for $150.
Proceeds from bag sales benefit Re:new, a nonprofit that provides employment opportunities for refugee women, and the Alto Mayo Forest Carbon Project in Peru, United said.
"United is committed to operating sustainably and responsibly, and that means finding creative ways to further reduce our impact on the environment," said Angela Foster-Rice, the airline's managing director of environmental affairs and sustainability.
The bags were designed by the Columbia College students to fit under airplane seats while being durable, wearable, economical and attractive, United said. United chose the winning designs, and Re:new produced the bags.
Find out more about how the bags were made here .
Southwest Airlines has done something similar. Earlier this year, it began shipping duffels and totes made from the leather of old aircraft seats. Looptworks of Portland, Ore., helped the airline turn 43 acres of discarded leather from 80,000 seats into bags.
